newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SingTel hits record low as rival grabs market.
newsitem.headline: SingTel hits record low as rival grabs market.

text.p: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel) shares hit an all-time low on Thursday on news that its rival mobile phone service had grabbed almost 10 percent of the local market in just three weeks, analysts said.
"Today's share price weakness is specifically related to the M1 (MobileOne) announcement," said Timothy Wong, an analyst at Vickers Ballas.
SingTel shares plunged to a record low of Singapore $2.50 (US$1.74) on Thursday before recovering to S$2.54 by the close of business, down eight cents on the day.
"The S$2.50 level was an all time low for SingTel," said one local analyst, who declined to be identified.
Wong said the fall was sparked by comments by M1 chief executive Neil Montefiore that the company had signed up more than 35,000 subscribers in just three weeks of operations.
"I don't want to use the word overwhelming, but the response has been way beyond our expectations," Montefiore told Reuters in an interview earlier on Thursday.
"In this first three weeks we must be the most successful entrant into any cellular market either initial, or second, or third, or whatever," he said.
MobileOne (Asia) Pte Ltd entered the Singapore cellular market on April 1 when mobile phone services were deregulated.
It is the only company to offer an alternative mobile phone service to former monopoly provider, SingTel.
M1 is a joint venture of Singapore Press Holdings, Keppel Telecom, Britain's Cable & Wireless and Hong Kong Telecommunications.
SingTel shares were listed four years ago and hit an all-time high of S$4.10 last year but have since fallen back as the liberalisation of its former monopoly markets loomed.
SingTel is due to lose its monopoly of basic telecommunications services in April 2000.
Several foreign companies, including British Telecom Plc and AT&T have said they may be interested in competing with SingTel from that date.
Another analyst who declined to be identified said the M1 news on Thursday had "aggravated the negative sentiment around SingTel".
But the analyst said he was confident SingTel's shares would recover once the company announced its 1997 annual results in May -- a sentiment shared by Wong.
"I think things will begin to look up when SingTel publishes its results," Wong said.
"When management comes out and says something about competition and gives some guidance on how revenues will be affected that will allay some fears," he said.
SingTel officials were not immediately available for comment on the company's share price or M1's claims for market share.
SingTel and M1 have been engaged in a fierce advertising war in the local media over the last month.
